description: They have pu-erh, my favorite black tea, so it makes for a great place to meet up with coffee loving friends or for interviews. Just be aware the seating inside is very limited, and outside can be noisy and chilly
author: Matthew D.

description:
"Coffee is a language in itself" -- Jackie Chan

And the "language" spoken in this small coffee shop in Embarcadero Center is smooth and pleasant, but it does not lack the required caffeine kick that we all look for when we toss up a shot of espresso or two! The barista's at this Embarcadero Center location are very friendly and good at what they do. 

Co-founders Gabriel Boscana and Robert Myers source and roast their coffee beans from Flying Goat Coffee, local importers in Healdsburg. They have a commitment to the local community and engage in charitable activities in the neighborhoods they operate. 

Read this to see how they are taking on climate change: https://goo.gl/DcJBUx
author: Afshin A.

description:
11am quick service.

Espresso drinks simplified - the cappuccino is disguised on the menu as "espresso + milk". Get it in a 12oz and it becomes a latte.

The ginger scone is fantastic and other varieties looked enticing.

Friendly service and non-pretentious espresso in a well designed space for an average San Franciscan price.
author: Monica H.

description: The coffee was really delicious, so I have to give them stars for that. However, if you are looking for a place to work, this wouldn't be my first pick. The actual place is very small with just a tiny little table to work. You can work at the tables outside though, but that's pretty weather-dependent (and knowing sf, it's most likely to just be cold and windy). Plus, no outlets is a thing. But if you're not coming to work, hit this place up for a good coffee.
author: Lee L.

description:
Great coffee in a great location. 

Secretly hidden inside the mall area right across the ferry building, Paramo serves espressos that are balanced in flavor and in a cute porcelain cup. There are also tables outside so that one could enjoy the sip with sunshine. 

This is the original location (Paramo roasting company), they also have a location on 9th street.
author: Elaine H.

description: Almost indistinguishable from Blue Bottle, (tastes like they roast their beans slightly longer though) but cute little location and with way shorter lines than the BB in the Ferry Building. Great little spot to drop into on your way to the embarcadero plaza shopping.
author: Virginia J.

description:
I like that they offer organic coffee. 
I also like that they offer paleo muffin options and sheep milk yogurt. 
Call me a snob, but they roast their beans a little too much for my taste.
author: Nathan M.

description: Hands down my favorite white marble countered hole in the wall coffee stop in SF. Try the cappuccino or the iced coffee. They have nice succulents too.
author: Spencer S.

description: Incredible espresso! Went here 4 times on my previous visit to SF. Big fan of their espresso. When I come back I will absolutely be coming back. Right around the corner from the Hyatt Regency as well.
author: Joe O.

description:
Paramo is in the breezeway of Four Embarcadero center. San Fran is not lacking in a selection of fantastic coffee, so deciding on my morning coffee stop is always a decision between excellent, superb, and phenomenal. I saw the reviews of Paramo and decided to give it a try. I was impressed that they used Califia Farms almond milk and anytime I can eliminate dairy without a knock to my coffee enjoyment, I'm game. 

The shop is small and narrow. I ordered a light roast filter coffee with almond milk and the cashier asked if I wanted the almond milk steamed, which was a great touch. The minus one star is for something I realized when I looked at my receipt in my email. They charged me $0.50 for the almond milk (standard upcharge) and ANOTHER $0.50 for steaming it. I think that is petty, steaming the milk takes seconds. My small drip coffee was amazing, but $4.50 for a little coffee seems a little steep IMHO. Will I go back? probably...will I like paying an additional $0.50 for the steamy goodness? Never
author: Sierra G.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, but the drip coffee was just not my thing. It's fruity and acidic, so, if that's your thing, this might be a great place for you! At $3 for a 12 oz cup, it's on the "cheaper" side for San Francisco coffee, but still pricey. 

I'd be interested in coming back to try a latte or espresso drink - I have a feeling those would be tasty. Service was excellent - staff was very friendly and accommodating.
author: Annie S.

description:
Good enough coffee for me, friendly baristas, quick service, it's perfect for a break.

This is purely personal, so at the risk of TMI, it's just far enough from my office to get away for a bit, but not so far that I have to run to get back to work. What I'm really looking for is an Italian-style coffee bar where nothing is to-go and customers stand around for a few minutes drinking out of real cups with saucers. Also, an espresso costs around one euro. In the absence of my dream place, this hits the spot.
author: David D.

description: Cute little coffee shop in the embarcadero. I really enjoyed their vanilla latte! It was just the right amount of sweet without being overpowering. They also offer almond milk for those who can't drink or don't like milk. When I visit coffee shops I look at not only their coffee but also the ambiance. The baristas were friendly and the coffee shop was really cute. I would definitely go again!
author: Salonee T.

description:
An 8 oz drip is $2.50.  That's expensive.  Anywhere else, $2.50 would get you at least 12 oz!  I think I'd be inclined to give Paramo 5 stars if their prices were a little more reasonable... But I still like this place.  I always go for whatever dark roast they have, and it's always good.  I love a good cup of dark coffee and they definitely have that down.

They've also got a good selection of pastries in the mornings!  The ginger scone is definitely worth getting and super filling (also priced at $2.50).

The place is small, so a bit of a line will look pretty long and go out the door, but it rarely takes more than a few minutes.  They've usually got 2 people working in the mornings - always very friendly!
author: Kenna H.

description:
Sometimes I like to get off one stop before work just so I can stop by Paramo for an almond latte! 

Tucked inside the one Embarcadero center, near Onigily! Lines never seem to be too long. It moves fast. It's a small shop so even when you're standing out the door, it's not as bad as it seems. 

I've yet to try anything else. I'm not super adventurous when it comes to trying new items. Once I find something I like, I tend to stick with it. I find that the times I do try somethings else, I never like it as much as my usual order. 

Simple menu. Friendly people. Fast!

7.15.15-omg, I just tried the bacon cheddar scone this morning. It's phenom!
author: Dianna C.

description: Love this place! The espresso and milk is perfect! Every time I go, the quality and taste are consistently wonderful. There aren't a lot of options but it's not a Starbucks. It's a place that caters to people who actually love coffee and don't need weird flavors added to it to enjoy it. Keep it up Paramo! You have a loyal customer right here.
author: Jenny C.

description: One of top coffee shop in san francisco. My usual order are regular latte. In my book, coffee here are better than blue bottle!
author: Dan A.

description:
Can there be enough coffeehouses in this town? Why yes, yes, there can be. Coffeehouses should be dark and have a skinny woman in a beret playing performing off-key Joni Mitchell songs on a stool. But now they're more about fair trade beans, blossom brewing, and expensive scones from an artisan bakery nobody's heard of. Like Reveille and Artis, Paramo is another indy alternative to the more successful caffeine chains like Philz and Blue Bottle. And like any coffeehouse in this city, it has its followers and detractors. After two visits, I have to say I'm probably a mild follower, the timid type who would stop by if I walked by their shop in Four Embarcadero but probably not give it much thought afterward.

Except I gave it enough thought to submit this review. I tried their $2.50, 12-ounce cup of filter coffee which was their Firecracker that day (photo: http://bit.ly/1hMTj1O). They describe that one as lively, bright and juicy - though those three adjectives seem misapplied to a coffee bean, more like a fruit-flavored chewing gum. I liked the basic flavor notes of it though it tasted a tad burnt. It was not nearly enough for me to throw the coffee in the barista's face. OK, I've never done that, I swear, but it was probably not freshly brewed which at 2PM, wasn't my expectation anyway. I'm not sure what the flying donkey on the cup means, but I assume it's their response to having a skinny woman singing on a stool in here.

COFFEE - 3 stars...pretty good though a tad burnt the last time
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...not much of it unless you count their merchandise on the shelves
SERVICE - 3 stars...quick
TOTAL - 3 stars...perhaps when donkeys fly
author: Ed U.

description:
First visited this place yesterday. It is a very nice spot. There is nice seating right in front of the barista station and as well as next door in the apartment lobby lounge. The wifi is great! Lots of windows which give great lighting. 

Coffee: Honestly, the coffee doesn't stand out that much but that is not to say that it is not good. It def has a good standard taste. 
Outlets: Many people were saying there are no outlets. In the main space, that is true. Move over to the lobby lounge area and they are in the couches. 
Service: Very friendly baristas. 

Def recommend if you need a spot to chill or study. Great vibes.
author: Jimmy M.

description:
I don't totally get the high reviews, but maybe my tastes just aren't refined enough for this coffee.

The 12-oz filter coffee cost $3.50--I figured the barista would filter it in the spot so I tipped a buck, but she just went to the back to pour the pre-brewed stuff into a cup. The only sweeteners they had in practice were Stevia in the Raw and agave syrup, since the raw sugar was caked to the bottom of the shaker. :| This made for some really gross-tasting coffee unfortunately, and I just ended up dumping it down the sink. Worst $4.50 I've ever spent.
author: Beck E.

description: Tucked away in a side alley next to the Embacadero Center is a dimly lit coffee shop. It's a no frills shop with barely any lighting and minimal seating (the outdoor benches were mostly occupied by bums). The baristas seemed very nice.  My latte was pretty good (a little light on body).  I preferred the blue bottle location in the Ferry Building during my visit.
author: Dingus M.

description:
LOVE!! 
Half steamed almond milk, half black coffee. 
Perfect for SF weather. 
Seriously in love with this place. Tastes just like the coffee I got in Europe. I have tried so many places around San Fran, but this is by far the best. 
The coffee lids don't spill while you walk, like 90% of the coffee places usually do. 
Felt confident while walking with a full cup in my hand. 

Thanks for making my morning 10x better. 

Yum!
author: Heidi K.

description:
Quick and convenient coffee (or expresso) with a character of it's own!  I'm a total Paramo fan after stopping by this place!  

The set up of this place is simple.  In one direction, out the other.  They've got bags for sale, pastries, and even cold drinks.  Chai, iced coffee, regular expresso, and even hot cocoa.  I also notice the sell the Chemex glass coffee maker, as well as my favorite the Aeropress!  

I ordered from the lovely lady with a smile, and started with a simple 8oz cup of filtered coffee.  It was love at first sip!  Bold yet pleasant!  It definitely made me feel upbeat!  Not to mention the aroma, definitely tranquil.  The next day I met up with a fellow yelper and ordered a Traditional kouign-amann pastry.  Holy buttery goodness Batman!  Way better than their almond croissant.  But then again, I believe all their pastries probably match well with their coffee.  Give this place a try, I guarantee you'll like it!  

Another cool thing about where this shop is located, are the wooden tables and chairs outside.  Like I said, it's a small in-n-out coffee shop.  Yet it's good to know you've got a comforting place to kick it and enjoy your coffee.  

If I have any regrets, it's one, not buying a bag of coffee beans.  And two, short changing Yelp on the pics, but I'll be back!  (^_^)
author: Ron R.

description:
My visit to Paramo on a Wednesday afternoon was as dreary and grey as the rainy weather outside. The 8oz espresso with milk I ordered was good, but not memorable or exceptional in smoothness or flavor for me. The service was equally lackluster. No one spoke a single word to me except to ask what I wanted to order. Maybe it was an off day, as I have only read glowing reviews from most every other Yelper having visited the spot. I was looking forward to the visit but I left rather disenchanted. 

Due to the plethora of other coffee shops in San Francisco I have yet to try and my experience here, Paramo is one of the shops that I likely won't return to.
author: Shirley V.

description:
My favorite coffee spot near the Embarcadero Center. The line is generally short, and the coffee is great. The people here are also very friendly. Shorter lines than Philz and better coffee than Starbucks/Peet's. You can't beat that.

They only have two sizes available though: 8 oz or 12 oz. Also, there is no seating inside.
author: Andrew L.

description: Wonderful coffee shop in a great location with lots of outdoor seating (as it is in the Embarcadero.) Great for meetings as opposed to most coffee shops that are filled with noise from blenders whipping and frapping about. The espresso based drinks were made with care, from very good coffee.
author: Nate W.

description: Hard to start my morning without their iced coffee! Bacon cheddar scones are also tasty. Lastly- people here are very nice and friendly!
author: Amanda L.

description:
This place is awesome.
The coffee menu is somewhat limited-no flavor shots-but that's not a uncommon at places that really know what they are doing when it comes to coffee. 
the basic coffee options are solid. The espresso is superior, and the latte's, cappuccino's etc. are delightful. The dirty chai is a standout item.
They outsource pastries and lunch items. these can be expensive (seven dollars or more for a sandwich) but are also outstanding.
The inside has a small counter but mostly people chose to sit outside in the courtyard/walkway running though embarcadero cente or better yet bierman park.
there are lines at times but they move quickly. The staff know what they are doing.
All in all there is a lot to like here.
author: Steven W.

description:
I do love a good coffee, that part's always been the case.  I love coffee on days when I especially need it. Like today. Or like every day.

I had randomly heard about Paramo via fb and knew that since it was right around the corner from where I work, it was definitely worth checking out. My co-worker and I stopped in this morning and the first thing we noticed was how clean the space is!  Sure there isn't a place for hipsters to congregate on their laptops and sit for hours on end, but is anyone really going to miss that? I had tried their Columbian coffee earlier on this week and thought it was enjoyable, and was happy to hear that Paramo rotates its coffee de jour all the time between their various beanz from around the world (Rwanda, Columbia, Guatemala, Indonesia, Sumatra, and a seasonal blend, to name a few).  For this time, I ordered the 4oz espress + milk and it was DELISH.  They had me at filtered, now they have me on espresso. swoon.

When I last came, there wasn't a food option, but today, there were a variety of items that seemed to have made their way into the shop!  Sweet croissants, savory croissants, muffins, and lo and behold, a cookie sandwich was available. If nothing else, I'm coming back for that cookie sammich.

So, it looks there's a little bit of neighborhood competition with Terminus, but as a consumer, I couldn't be more pleased with this dilemma for my morning caffeine fix.
author: Lisa I.

description:
After missing the PresidioGo shuttle, my friend and I decided to find a local coffee shop. Next, we found Paramo and it looked cute. I remembered to bring my mason jar, so I was able to get a 50 cent discount on my chai. I like the variety of drinks and I look forward to visiting in the future. 

It is close to transit and walkable. Bicycle parking may be hard to find. There is no free wi-fi. The counters inside have hooks to hang bangs/backpacks.
author: Kristal C.

description: This is my favorite coffee spot near work. I come here often for the Chai Tea which is made with Tipu's. I am truly addicted to the spices! I love that the Chai isn't overly sweet and just gives much kick with the spices. I came here the other day and tried the Costa Rica brew which was delicious and flavorful - zero burnt taste whatsoever, 10x better in taste than your typical Starbucks or Peets black drip coffee. This is definitely my favorite spot to get away from it all and recharge during a busy work day. Oh yes and the paper cups they use are SUPER awesome, there's an imprint of Pegasus looking donkey.
author: Michelle T.

description: Ordered a mocha (espress + milk + coca) which at $5 is the normal price for a hipster specialty drink. The place lacks decor but the drink was great and I'll definitely return for more!
author: Alfonso C.

description: great location!! it's so nice to sip a cup of coffee while sitting at the tables right outside :) latte art was super cute!! however, I would've liked my 8 oz. a little stronger. 8 oz. is usually my perfect ratio at coffee shops like blue bottle and verve, but paramo is a little weaker in coffee flavor. but if you're a fan of more watered down coffee, paramo is great!
author: Hannah C.

description:
Wee little coffee shop in the Embarcadero center. I've been here twice now and both experiences have been quite pleasant. There's usually only one barista working, or at least that's the case on the weekend. They are friendly and helpful.

They also sell pastries from Starter Bakery. I haven't had a chance to try but they look delicious.

They don't have any seating in the shop, but there's general seating outside. 

[TIP] If you get a buy a bag of coffee beans (~$16-17), you get a complimentary small cup of coffee! They offer a variety of beans that range from bright to balanced to rich.
author: Lucy N.

description: Great place to get coffee and a scone - mind you, this is not Starbucks, so don't ask for a frappe anything or whatever gob of sugary drink to mask bad coffee. Paramo has coffee that warms the soul and is refined. Come here if you want an artisan cup of coffee. I tend to come in for the drip coffee, but on occasion, I'll treat myself to a mocha - and it's divine. People have mentioned it's expensive, but I don't find that to be true - it's downtown plus this is third wave coffee.
author: Grayson E.

description:
Paramo is a small coffee spot in Embarcadero 4. The coffee is high quality, but a little too intense/bitter for my taste. (The coffees are also on the smaller side. I can finish one in three large gulps.) However, if you like dark roasts, Paramo is worth a try.

Side note: The baked goods from Muffin Revolution are delicious! The Banana Bam-Bam is my favorite even though it's not a traditional muffin. So good.
author: Connie Q.

description:
I had what amounts to a mocha; they call it espresso+milk+chocolate or some other fancy name. The drink came with latte art and the entire vibe of the cafe is spot-on; clean, hipster, and so very California (complete with hella clean spoons). The drink was delicious, just the perfect amount of bittersweet chocolate, milk, and great espresso. 

I also enjoyed some gluten-free paleo date chocolate muffin that was as delicious as it was expensive. Overall, $9 for an 8oz. drink and dessert, but I expected it; worth every dollar. The mocha rivals any chocolate drink I've had in a long time.
author: Eldin D.

description:
Great espresso served in unique stone cups. And bonus for points for also providing bubbly water to clean the palate! 

I've only tried the espresso, but they also have baked goods and salads. Vegan options available.

This is my go-to choice for coffee when I'm working nearby or passing through.
author: Andrew H.

description: The best coffee place in the Fi-Di.  An awesome flat white. Reminds me of a Melbourne flat white.   Worth a visit and one of the best coffees in the city, and certainly the best in the 'hood.
author: Scott H.

description: No lines at 4:30pm. Their chai lattes are made from real tea, not that concentrate stuff. Would return if I'm in the area
author: Lisa H.

description: The coffee was just coffee nothing to rave about but nothing to complain either. THE real gem is the ginger scone!! Moist, crystal sugary top, and small chunks of chewy delicious ginger. #yesplease
author: Jillian S.

description: I got off Bart and found this hidden coffee shop at Embarcadero. It was nice and clean. I love the atmosphere and their coffee was good.
author: Janine C.

description: Granted I've been limited to the immediate area around the Hyatt, but this is the best latte I've found here. Solid taste, good prep. Typical food offerings. Note this is not a place to hang out as there's no room to do so.
author: Todd K.

description: Great coffee and always a warm welcome in the morning. The cashier is always smiling
author: Lea L.

description:
Gibraltar Review

The Pour:
Decent, on par with Ritual, as an example. Like almost every shop in San Francisco, I feel like they're roasted too light or something, so you get a "lemon bomb" when you sip it, as one barista put it. That seems to be the preference for San Francisco drinkers, so....

Service:
My barista (I think his name is Cole) was super friendly and personable.

Ambiance:
Super clean and modern, it's a very small shop without seating, tucked in the alleyway area of Embarcadero 4 across from the Ferry Building. They have a great minimalist menu, which includes a single line item for Espresso + Milk, which I think is super logical!

Conclusion:
Decent Third Wave shop overall. I'd go there instead of Blue Bottle in the Ferry Building for sure

About Me / Review Criteria:
-I only check out / review "Third Wave"/artisanal/craft coffee shops
-Nobody gets more than 4 stars until I've gone several times
-Reviews can't be based on just a select group of baristas, they all have to be equally skilled, or at least must all have a minimum level of skill
-My star ratings are solely based on the drink, never on food, ambiance, or if the barista is emo or snobby (because that would bring down more than 50% of the shops), although I do mention those in the review
-I don't claim to be a trained coffee connoisseur
-My reviews are generally based on gibraltar/cortados (or cappuccinos), not espresso or drip/pourover coffee
author: Bernard F.

description: Excellent cappuccino. Delicious and beautiful. Tucked in the alley by the Hyatt embarcasero.
author: gary g.

description:
What makes Paramo special is their staff. Sure, the coffee is great, but there are lots of good coffee shops in San Francisco. The folks working at Paramo are what puts this shop head and shoulders above the others. 

Staff is friendly, helpful, and fast. They're more like friends than service workers. Hard to imagine a better place to get a cup.
author: Greg K.

description:
Amazing coffee. If you don't feel like waiting in long lines and have a 5 star coffee definitely stop here. 
They are less than a year old but they have got the 'it' factor 
They are definitely up there with the top coffee spots in the Bay Area and an added bonus. 
The staff if very friendly and non pretentious. 

I had friends in town from east coast and they were quite friendly and tool time to explain their art.
author: Foodie C.

description:
Paramo is good, it's in an odd location because I want to open multiple Paramos across SF.  

Their roast heavily reminds me of my favorite coffee shop in New York which would be the Stumptown in the Ace Hotel.  That reminder alone is worth the measly $2 they charge for a cup of small coffee.  

The roast is somewhat acidic, robust and packs a nice kick of caffeine.  It brightens my chilly SF day way up with their individually ink rolled paper cups.  

I even love the old white tiled walls and Marzocco expresso machines which reminds me of old coffee shops that are littered throughout Spain and my beloved La Colombe in Philadelphia. 

Glad I get to write the 22nd review since that is my favorite number and I hope that this review brings you more patrons.  You guys rock.
author: Andrew T.

description:
I am here for work and was so sick of the hotel coffee (I'm staying at the Hyatt), so I ventured out and got a cappuccino from here.  The cappuccino was amazing, I just finished as I am typing this review.

The customer service was good as well, not flashy and no fake smiles.  I will get another cup tomorrow before I leave.
author: Eddie H.

description:
Great no-frills type coffee and friendly staff! I got a latte and mocha, both of which were delicious. Options are 8oz and 12oz. I got whole milk for both, but they have other substitutes (almond milk, low-fat, etc.)

Try the chocolate kouign amann, which is perfectly flaky and buttery. The chia pudding with nuts and dried fruit in the fridge is interesting, but also great. 

Another plus is that there has been little or no wait at all at the times I went. I think this will be my next go-to spot for coffee!
author: Madonna N.

description:
Confession: I'm not really an expert on coffee. 

This is a small place that apparently serves high quality coffee according to the coffee experts of Yelp. There isn't anywhere to sit inside, which is a bit of a bummer since, for me, that (+ the smell) is one of the main attractions of a cafe. They have a simple and concise menu (i.e. espresso, espresso + milk, and that's pretty much it) along with some pastries as well. I had them add cocoa to my espresso + milk (which might have been frowned upon), but I found my self-assembled mocha to be quite delicious.
author: Madhur B.

description:
A really good coffee spot, giving Blue Bottle a run for it's money.

Slim little spot inside the Embarcadero 4 ground floor, good thing there did not seem to be a crowd.

Sampled Gibraltars and Latte's on a recent visit, all excellent.
author: Patrick S.

description: Good service and pretty designs but coffee and hot cocoa were average and lukewarm. Convenient location for tourists.
author: Pri A.

description: Love this coffee place. Great almond latte, normal coffee even espresso. Their cookies and muffins are delicious and fresh!
author: Karolina C.

description:
Paramo is a newly opened small coffee shop situated in the food alley between Hyatt and Four Embarcadero Center. The space is small and clean with minimal decoration. The ambience is not too cozy but it is not uninviting either. They do not have chairs inside but there are chairs out in the alley, which  is a good area to settle down and enjoy their coffee.

You can tell that the staff are fiercely proud of their product. Watching the barista prepare my caffe Americano with such intensity coupled with their claim of "slow sipping coffee" made me expect a great coffee. And they delivered. The coffee is bold without any hint of burnt bitterness. It really is a drink to savor in your mouth, much like you would with great wine.

Paramo is a great addition to the area and a fantastic substitute to the corporate coffee shops that surround the area. I will be back.
author: Clarice O.

description:
I've been coming here a lot recently and really find it unique. I usually get a double espresso, but have tried the latte as well. When you get an espresso to stay, they give you a side of seltzer water, which is a nice touch and helps keep the palate fresh. I like the dark roast and the rich (but not too much) crema, but I really enjoy the sour finish to their espresso. It's almost enough to cause you to squint, but not quite. It's definitely a "hurts so good" kind of experience if I may be so bold as to quote JC Mellencamp.  

The service is fantastic and the staff/owners are very knowledgeable and passionate.  I hate to think about how tough it must be to make rent at 4 EC given the ridiculous commercial real estate market in SF.  However, they seem to have good traffic and they keep it pretty simple. I highly recommend!
author: Kenneth N.

description:
As an Australian travelling to the US for the first time, I've struggled to find good espresso-style coffee that was comparable to back home. Most places have either been terrible, expensive or both.

Paramo is somewhat pricey (thanks to the terrible exchange rate), but the coffee is good and the service is efficient and friendly.
author: Weng C.

description: Best late I had here so far. Balanced, clean medium roast. A bit hidden at the back of the building, but if you don't want pour over in Tha front, but rather the more classic delightful potion, come here.
author: A S.

description: Tried some muffin-aptly named home for the holidays..paleo,gluten and dairy-free! Can't get better than this!
author: Priyanka L.

description:
The Ethiopian Stargazer over ice was described as amazing by the barista behind the counter. I swear my brain produced some kind of endorphin with the first sip. 

I had to buy a pound of something to take home. I failed at the proper brewing system and it wasn't as good at home. But Paramo's professional baristas will surely take the time to advise me next time I visit.

Definitely a stop in SF if you're a true coffee fanatic.  And convenient location at the Hyatt Embarcadero/ BART for tourist passing through or Bay Area family members who need a break as tour guides.
author: Marlenee H.

description: The service here is super friendly. Paramo is a no-frills kinda place with a handful of drink options. Their iced coffee is great, especially with a smidgen of simple syrup and a dash of their high quality chilled almond milk (no pacific breeze boxed junk here!)
author: Nicole O.

description:
If you're serious about coffee, this is where you want to be.

Paramo carries 7 distinct lines of coffees, one of which is a decaf and another is an espresso blend. They go down the line from full bodied and toasty to the light and floral fruity beans. They seem to rotate the origin of their blends based on grower availability, so the bag of Stargazer (my favorite) may come from one region one month, then another the next. 

This isn't bad per se, the lines have static flavor profiles, and while you might pick some different flavors in the tasting notes as the regions change, the SPIRIT of what the coffee is supposed to evoke remains the same.

I come in often enough that the staff knows me by name, they know a lot of regulars names and orders actually. They're all very nice and seem to be genuinely enthusiastic about coffee, backed up by sight of an often in use Chemex behind the counter. I'd like to see pourovers on the menu, but given the size of the shop and the volume of customers they see, it just isn't feasible. Expanding on that, the menu is very straightforward, coffee on drip, espresso, espresso+milk (it's just easier than listing every permutation), teas which I've never tried, ditto for the cocoa.

They have some wonderful pastries behind the counter, some rotate based on what fruit is in season, but I've never had one I didn't like. Try the Kouign Amann (pronounced Queen Uh Mon).

The space is small, with a maximum of four seats at the bar, but there is plenty of seating outside. Their location is pretty interesting, nestled in the Embarcadero Center right next to the Hyatt, they don't suffer the throngs of tourists Blue Bottle patrons have to elbow out of the way at the Ferry Building, or the bandwagon hype fans of the newly opened Philz on Market, but they have been successful enough to have a second location opening soon.

 It's the best 3rd wave coffee shop in FiDi by a wide margin.

Go.
author: Miguel L.

description:
Coffee has personality, cup with the picture of a flying donkey was funny and service was very nice. Will come again!

However, please post a permanent note in the window if there is a lunch break. So that people don't specifically come at 12:09pm on a Saturday to get their coffee, just to see a note that you are on a lunch break until 1pm.
author: Paula S.

description:
Paramo serves exceptional espresso drinks. They are a bit on the bright/acidic  side, which is why some people might not like them. From time to time they can also be a little hot.

That being said, I go here often and the espresso drinks are consistently terrific. The espresso is flavorful and works well with milk. They currently get white label espressos from Flying Goat in Healdsburg. The texture of the drink is smooth and rich. The flavor is differentiated from the other major roasters in the city, which is a big plus for me, since I go to Ritual and Blue Bottle pretty often.

The space is slim, so don't look for seating inside. They are very efficient though, and there is rarely much of a line. Great for a to go cup.
author: Erik S.

description:
Good strong coffee
Nice outdoor seating in the shade
No place to drink inside but shelter seating
   Under a canopy between 2 bldgs
author: S.K. Y.

description: The sweetest staff EVER!  Owners are hella lucky.  Gluten free pastries, small selection of refrigerated drinks.  I recommend anything there, though.  Much faster then the Blue Bottle option across the street.  Small area to sit, but most folks are running to work anyway.  Music is always really good.
author: Linda L.

description: I got a decaf coffee to go with my onigiri from next door. It was ok. The barista was very nice and helpful but the coffee did not taste that good.
author: Amy V.

description: I just had the best cup of chai I have ever had, hands down. This place, like much of SF, is on the pricy side. $3 for an 8oz cup. But it's totally worth it.
author: Connie K.

description:
I cant understand the good reviews. This is the first time I ever poured out a $4 cup of coffee in the bushes. The first cup I asked for was an iced coffee-which was already made and in a pot-which I questioned the barista about because, in my opinion, it's "old" after sitting. But she assured me the pots were air pots [no air can get inside] so I went for it. It was over the top bitter. I never do this either-but I went back and asked for an americano since I couldn't drink the iced coffee due to extreme bitterness. I respectfully did this in a low voice so no other patrons could hear me. Well, the americano was also extremely bitter. I love good coffee and can usually suffer through even a Starbucks coffee if I have to. But this was a bitterness I've never tasted before. I won't be back. 
This coffee shop is very cute and looks like it would have been very good. What a disappointment! Lesson learned.
author: Sharon S.

description: Wow, I just had the best cup of Chai Latte! I like my Chai Latte bitter and less on the sweeter side and Paramo met my Chai satisfaction! I ordered it in a 12 oz for $4, it's on the pricey side, but I'd rather pay a dollar more for quality coffee. I came in at 9:12 am and I was immediately greeted with smiles and hellos from 3 employees. They seemed to enjoy their jobs and props to them for probably waking up at 6 am for work every morning. It was my first time here and this place is definitely better than Starbucks and Philz. Paramo is conveniently located in the Embartcadero Center next to work and I will definitely try their Ethiopian Coffee during my next  visit. They also have daily specials :) Something for customers like myself to look forward to every morning!
author: Debby L.

description: There are baristas and there are baristas who love their jobs and customers. Best in SF bay both for outstanding espresso and service. A subtle notch above blue bottle, sightglass, chromatic, ritual, cento, coffee culture, etc.
author: Vijay B.

description:
Best dang cappuccino in town! Great single varietal coffees and espressos. 

Paramo is exactly what you would want in a take-away coffee shop - exceptional coffee, super friendly staff, efficient, inexpensive. I'm not really a milk-substitute kinda guy, but they nail the almond-milk variety.  There are a few tables right in front if you want to stay a while and drink your beverage from the beautiful ceramic cups they have. 

p.s. If you happen to meet Gabe at the barista bar you're in for a special treat - he's also the roaster of these amazing coffees. Ask him to tell you more about the coffees and what he likes about them.
author: Josh C.

description:
not sure why this place has such great reviews


the coffee i just got was under extracted and really acidic.  at the price point i expected it to be pour over or something.  not just poured out of a large insulated carafe.

back to phillz for me....or even peet's
author: Bryan H.

description:
I just stopped in here for the second time, and it'll definitely be my go to place at work. The place is BEAUTIFUL: simple white tile and wood. Small glass case with amazing pastries.

I got the ginger scone the first time I was in, and that was a nice surprise, if a bit too cakey for my tastes. Today I got a classic (something I can't pronounce) that sort of looks like a croissant that's been folded into a muffin tin. It was carmel-y and a little sticky, with just the right amount of savory. SO GOOD.

They have two coffee sizes that also feel quite right: 8oz and 12oz. No trenta here, thank god.

The other thing I really like is what's NOT there: no crap by the cash register. No overplayed jazz standards on the Muzak. No menu overwrought with complicated, corporate products. No blaring digital monitor. Just simple solid coffee.
author: Ryan C.

description: Coffee too sour for my liking.  The worst part are their togo cups....lids don't fit right and massive spillage as you're walking.  They double cup it instead of using sleeves which causes issues.  This is what I get for trying hipster coffee and straying from the major players
author: Vince L.

description: The best coffee in the city however it is too bad that the place does not have wifi. I go there pretty much everyday in the morning with my sister and the staffs are super friendly.
author: Garnett S.

description:
With a friendly, cordial staff and never too long of a wait, Paramo has finally filled the good-coffee micro-dearth in the heart of the FiDi for those of us too lazy to walk across the embarcadero or over toward SOMA.

Paramo has become the trusty "regular" coffee shop amongst my office's ring of caffeine-deprived and addicted coffee and espresso connoisseurs. They're still relatively new to the area and they're always making small adjustments (last week they finally got Square).
author: Alyssa W.

description:
I used to frequent Paramo. Everyone there's great, and the coffee is fair (a little on the tangy side for drip but I was into it). Espresso was done right. However, as someone else mentioned- they just upped their prices for drip $1 a cup. So an 8oz is $3 and a 12oz is $3.50. I realize they were on the "slightly lower" end of cost for roasters in the area at $2.50 for a 12oz beforehand, but it wasn't a steal. Couldn't you just raise it a quarter a cup-maybe 50 cents max? Charging the same price for coffee out of an urn when other shops only charge you that much if they're pouring it by hand isn't right. So sadly, I've made a vow to never return for my morning cup.

On the bright side though, they don't rip you off on pastry prices, compared to Philz around the block!
author: Victor N.

description: The coffee was good, but kind of expensive for how small a cup we got. The ginger scone was crumbly and yummy. There was not really any seating inside but the outdoor seating area was nice and the service was fast.
author: Jackie P.

description: Ordered the espresso with almond milk. Such a delicious cup of coffee. It's super smooth with just enough bite at the end. I only wish they would stay open later.
author: Zaynab A.

description: I am not a regular coffee drinker (seriously, 2-4 cups/mo.) but when I do need a cup of coffee, this is my go-to. Friendly servers and their pastries are great; especially the Kouign-amann.
author: Chris P.

description:
Walked in at 5:01:

"Oh, we're closed."

"What about that guy who you're cashing out?"

"He walked in before you, when we weren't closed. But you can have this coffee I was going to throw out."

Sir, I'm going to have to have you eat our trash, then leave: now I know what Rob Schneider's life is like.

PS I drank the coffee, forever sullying the crest of the family P.,  so this review has no credibility.

PPS In a bid to boost my credibility, I'll describe the coffee: "heat, but beany." The garbage wasn't missing much. Then again, most coffee tastes like this, so three stars seem fair.
author: Matvei P.

description: Love this small coffee shop in the embarcadero center near Osha Thai. Usually there is no wait, the coffee is pretty good and people are nice. I would love to get some nice snacks items too. Coffee was initially too much roasted but they altered the composition And now tastes great. A good alternative for blue bottle.
author: Suyog D.

description: Great strong coffee and childish gambino playing in the background all morning. Super super super nice people in there too. Good croissants
author: Justin H.

description: Great cappuccino, not too expensive for a well-crafted espresso drink! Place to go for a quick fix of espresso.
author: Henry P.

description:
Paramo is a great little coffee shop to check out. 

Their head roaster, Gabe, makes the coffee up in Healdsburg. Its great to see another new face in the San Francisco 3rd Wave coffee scene. For those of us who have to commute or work near the Embarcadero, this is a wonderful new spot to take a break.

The interior is very clean and incorporates a fair amount of bright, white tiles and rustic woodwork. 

If you are in the market for buying coffee beans, check out the Workhorse - its great for a pick-me-up in the afternoon and packs some punch. 

The staff is young and knowledgeable about coffee.
author: Kristian H.

description: I love this place! I come here almost everyday for an iced espresso before work and am greeted with smiles/laughter from all the staff. Definitely makes me feel at home and happy  to support a high quality small business  keep up the smiles and delicious cups! Oh try to get the bacon cheddar scone yummmmmm
author: Jasmine P.

description: Great vibe, the people are really nice. The coffee is even better, check out this little gem!
author: Philip D.

description:
Balanced.

Still exceptional Guy J compliation: http://inthemix.com/news/guy-j-to-mix-the-next-balance-presents-compilation/293

Quite exceptional Paramo creation: Flywheel featuring Colombian beans that are so smooth milk and syrups are not necessary. 2% available if you do want some.

Just one of a few proprietary blends in this small, well design, friendly, enthusiastic Embarcadero coffee shop. Simple, straightforward and just $2.50.

You can get Guy J on Spotify. You can get more info on Flywheel here: http://www.paramocoffee.com/collections/paramos-coffee-lineup/products/flywheel

Get both.
author: Jason B.

description: My 2nd visit. My recommendation is to get a Latte or Cappuccino with Almond Milk. It makes my day!
author: Seiko I.

description: Good coffee, service with a smile (and speed!) and amazing pastries by way of Starter Bakery.
author: Vivek S.

description: Finally posting - good, bold-flavored espresso! Pastries, specifically the fruit danish, is yummy. The best staff - friendly, always make you feel welcome :)
author: Katherine L.

description: Shoot! Almost simultaneously to when I wrote my 5/19 review, they stopped carrying sandwiches.  Which means, I have no use for yet another over-priced coffee klatch.
author: Kai T.

description: Delicious, small batch coffee and a super friendly crew. Check it out.
author: Eric W.

description: $2 for a 10oz cup makes me think this is going to be some great tasting freshly made coffee. Nope.
author: Jacob L.

description: Paramo has become my go-to coffee spot, as I really enjoy the bitter cocoa notes of their espresso & milk. It is also nice to have the option for a smaller 8 oz latte, for days when I crave more espresso than milk. The people who work here are friendly and attentive, and I haven't had a bad drink yet, of the dozen or so times that I have been here. The quality is outstanding, and it is refreshing not to have to stand in a 10-person-long line to get a coffee.
author: Patricia D.

description: Because the Blue Bottle Coffee line is usually long and slow, I walked across the street into the Hyatt open corridor and found this place. Latte was excellent - I find myself coming here now rather than the Ferry Building. Shhh...before anyone finds out about this place and the lines become long too.
author: Robert B.

description: It was afternoon. I was staying at a hotel nearby and needing a caffeine boost. I'm not a big Starbucks fan. So, I went to Paramo. I ordered a flat white and was very pleased--not cheap, but the perfect size (i.e., relatively small) and perfectly executed, with the right combination of espresso and milk and a smooth taste. Required no sugar (which, in my opinion, is the sign of a good flat white). Service was polite and efficient.
author: Craig P.

description: RUN don't walk to this coffee shop! I had the best espresso with milk ever! Distinct flavor, friendly staff and quick service. I may need to find a job near this coffee house. Bonus for offering gluten free and paleo breakfast muffins. Skip Starbucks, Blue Bottle, Petes etc. and go straight to Paramo!
author: K S.

description: This is a cute coffee shop tucked between Embarcadero Center and Justin Herman Plaza. The line is never long but service is swift. I usually get the 8 oz. espresso with whole milk. The coffee is a little fruity for me, but the milk sweetens and balances the drink. Interior is clean and simple and the girl who works there in the mornings has the best lipsticks. NARS junkies unite!
author: Bella L.

description: Best coffee in the Financial District. Simple menu with super high quality coffee served by friendly staff.
author: Will F.

description: In an area that is full of coffee options, I go out of my way to get this coffee. It's good...like really good. If you're a bit of a coffee snob like I am, go now. Think, dare I mention, Blue Bottle without the damn wait. It's just as good, if not better, and faster. Their ginger scones aren't bad either. Cool dudes, great service.
author: Susan Y.

description: Solid coffee shop with nice staff. Space is a bit small and tight. The sugar dispenser/holder is a large jug with a rabbit head on top... This thing is very hard to use/the sugar gets stuck, and if not careful a oversized mound of sugar can be sitting in the bottom of your coffee
author: Stephen L.

description: Great coffee! Love the grinds for brew and espresso.Skilled baristas.
author: Alex S.

description:
Had a latte which was kind of bitter and not very smooth. It didn't help that the guy making it coughed into my cup.

The coffee is very rich, so if you're into that then this might be the place for you. In my opinion it's not as good as nearby Blue Bottle and Workshop Cafe
author: Keith L.

description: If you are looking for a good shot of espresso, look no further. I've stopped by a few times to grab an espresso, and although a different person has pulled the shot each time, the quality is consistent. I love the location too: there is plenty of shared seating outside (although I tend to stand inside by the bar). It's definitely a no-frills shop; low foot print and no Paramo-only seating, but it is a great place.
author: Joshua S.

description: The coffee was great, but the size small is tiny. I also got a spinach feta croissant, which would have been a lot better if it were warmed up. But the service was quick and friendly, and there's a lot of outdoor seating nearby.
author: Audrey M.

description: Nice little place with friendly, enthusiastic baristas and great coffee. A nice alternative to the chain coffee shops nearby.
author: David B T.

description: Very good coffees, cool branding and style throughout. The espressos are well done and generally all the drinks look delish. Also tried their decaf Stargazer whole bean coffee and its def top 3 decafs I've tasted, very tasty.
author: Hasan L.

description: I had the carrot paleo muffin. It was good, but extremely overpriced. The aesthetic of the cafe was nice, but there was nowhere to sit inside except for a small bar with stools obstructed by the line of customers waiting to order. A good place for a quick on-the-go caffeine boost, but don't expect a full sit-down experience.
author: Sarah L.

description: Exactly the type of coffee shop I need! They serve coffee, espresso, simple tea and they have optional almond milk! They also have stevia!! I like my coffee plain and black. For $2 for an 8oz, this is definitely a winner for me....none of that whip cream, caramel, upside down, extra add-ons kind of "coffee."  True coffee for real coffee lovers! Oh and they have pastries and cookies too that I have yet to try, but they all look so delicious!
author: Nicest K.

description: I cannot say enough good things about this coffee shop.  Their staff is friendly and knowledgeable.  The shop itself is small, but they still manage to make if feel very quaint and peaceful.  Their drip coffee is super good!  If you buy a bag of whole bean coffee from them, I recommend the firecracker!  I have not been able to get the taste of their coffee out of my head!  As a self-proclaimed coffee connoisseur, it is a must try for anyone and definitely on my top five coffee shops in the bay area.
author: Johnathan W.

description: Good coffee, esp. The light roasts, friendly staff, solid!  I came for a taste and left with a bag.  The latte prep was good as well, had the yamyam gluten free muffin and it was pretty solid but not dry.  Small shop, not overdone.
author: Tico B.

description: I love my coffee. Love it.  Was hoping this would be a good competitor with Blue Bottle, but it doesn't quite measure up. Not bad at all, but for the price, it's worth walking to the Ferry Building and going for the real thing!
author: M D.

description: Best coffee in Embarcadero/Fidi! Both Kian and Gabe are really lovely, coffee is consistently smooth and never burnt. Good muffin selection too.
author: Alice T.

description: Paramo is my favorite coffee shop pretty much ever. Tiny place with super quick payment, emailed receipt, nice employees and you get your coffee in two seconds. I'm not even a huge fan of coffee in general but their 12oz regular drip with room for cream and a dash of sugar is something I look forward to, and I like it better than blue bottle.
author: Jordan H.

description:
i've started drinking coffee black and aside from philz there aren't many that has a flavor good enough on its own to do so... until i tried paramo! really good coffee. follow them on twitter to see what they're brewing for the day. 

p.s. this is no 2 pumps of vanilla, swirl of caramel, extra whip kinda place. pure coffee is all you're getting.
author: Jackie B.

description: Small shop with knowledgeable staff. Several coffee blends to choose from - great variety. I bought a bag of their Flywheel beans for $17 and am excited to try. Had a cup of their Workhorse and this blend was great - very full bodied and tasty. I would definitely go here again - it's nice to find a smaller place in Fidi and I do agree that this place is good competition to Blue Bottle, Reveille, and illy.
author: Lindsay N.

description: Great coffee, beautiful space, friendly service.
author: E W.

description: Friendly, warm staff.  Great, rich coffee and espresso.  A limited, but consistently good selection of treats including reduced guilt Paleo muffins.
author: J J.

description: New coffee destination in the financial district with amazing coffee offerings! Probably the best cappuccino I've had in years.  Might even be better than Abraço, my favorite coffee place until now.  Staff are young but eager to serve with a smile.
author: B L.
